name: 1-propanone, 1-(2-hydroxy-5-methylphenyl)-
Reason: The target compound is a derivative of benzene with additional functional groups: a propyl ketone (-CO-CH2-CH2-CH3) and a hydroxy-methyl group (-C(OH)-CH3). Benzene has a melting point of 5.5. The propyl ketone will likely decrease the melting point because of the reduction in symmetry and potential disruptive effect on crystal packing, which is typically -25 to -30. The hydroxy group, being capable of hydrogen bonding, tends to increase the melting point; however, when attached to a methyl group its effect is smaller, around +15 to +20. The added methyl group (orthogonal to hydroxy group) should have a slight increase due to its nonpolar character and increased molecular weight, usually around +5. Combining these adjustments, the anticipated effect on melting point would be: Starting from benzene (5.5), subtracting 25 for propyl ketone, adding 15 for the hydroxy group, and adding 5 for the methyl group.
